017package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
018
019/**
020 * Various trigonometric approximations, using a lookup table for sin() and cos(), a non-tabular approximation for
021 * sinSmooth() and cosSmooth(), a Padé approximant for tan(), and Taylor series for the inverses of sin(), cos(), and
022 * tan(). This supplies variants for radians, degrees, and turns. This also has an atan2() approximation defined with
023 * output in radians, degrees, and turns. The lookup-table-based sin() and cos() can be extraordinarily fast if the 64KB
024 * table can stay in a processor cache, while the "smooth" approximations may have higher quality but perform less
025 * quickly compared to an in-cache lookup table.
026 * <br>
027 * This is primarily derived from libGDX's MathUtils class. The main new functionalities are the variants that take or
028 * return measurements in turns, smooth/non-tabular sinSmooth() and cosSmooth(), and double variants in
029 * general.
030 * <br>
031 * The asin(), acos(), and atan() methods all
032 * use Taylor series approximations from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND
033 * Corporation; though one might think such code would be obsolete over 60 years later, the approximations from that
034 * study seem to have higher accuracy and speed than most attempts in later decades, often those aimed at DSP usage.
035 * Even older is the basis for sinSmooth() and cosSmooth(); the versions here are updated to be more precise, but are
036 * closely related to a 7th-century sine approximation by Bhaskara I. The update was given in
037 * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">this Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>. Also from Stack Exchange,
038 * <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer by Soonts</a> provided the tan()
039 * approximation used here.
040 */
041public final class TrigTools {
042
043    /**
044     * Not meant to be instantiated.
045     */
046    private TrigTools() {
047    }
048
049    /**
050     * The {@code float} value that is closer than any other to
051     * <i>pi</i>, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its
052     * diameter.
053     */
054    public static final float PI = (float) Math.PI;
055    /**
056     * The {@code double} value that is closer than any other to
057     * <i>pi</i>, the ratio of the circumference of a circle to its
058     * diameter.
059     */
060    public static final double PI_D = Math.PI;
061    /**
062     * 1.0f divided by {@link #PI}.
063     */
064    public static final float PI_INVERSE = (float) (1.0 / Math.PI);
065    /**
066     * 2f times {@link #PI}; the same as {@link #TAU}.
067     */
068    public static final float PI2 = PI * 2f;
069    /**
070     * 2f times {@link #PI}; the same as {@link #PI2}.
071     */
072    public static final float TAU = PI2;
073    /**
074     * {@link #PI} divided by 2f; the same as {@link #ETA}.
075     */
076    public static final float HALF_PI = PI * 0.5f;
077    /**
078     * {@link #PI} divided by 2f; the same as {@link #HALF_PI}.
079     */
080    public static final float ETA = HALF_PI;
081    /**
082     * 1.0 divided by {@link #PI}.
083     */
084    public static final double PI_INVERSE_D = (1.0 / Math.PI);
085    /**
086     * 2.0 times {@link Math#PI}; the same as {@link #TAU_D}.
087     */
088    public static final double PI2_D = Math.PI * 2.0;
089    /**
090     * 2.0 times {@link Math#PI}; the same as {@link #PI2_D}.
091     */
092    public static final double TAU_D = PI2_D;
093    /**
094     * {@link Math#PI} divided by 2.0; the same as {@link #ETA_D}.
095     */
096    public static final double HALF_PI_D = Math.PI * 0.5;
097    /**
098     * {@link Math#PI} divided by 2.0; the same as {@link #HALF_PI_D}.
099     */
100    public static final double ETA_D = HALF_PI_D;
101    /**
102     * {@link #PI} divided by 4f.
103     */
104    public static final float QUARTER_PI = PI * 0.25f;
105
106    /**
107     * {@link Math#PI} divided by 4.0.
108     */
109    public static final double QUARTER_PI_D = Math.PI * 0.25;
110
111    /**
112     * Multiply by this to convert from radians to degrees.
113     */
114    public static final float radiansToDegrees = 180f / PI;
115    /**
116     * Multiply by this to convert from degrees to radians.
117     */
118    public static final float degreesToRadians = PI / 180f;
119
120    /**
121     * Multiply by this to convert from radians to degrees.
122     */
123    public static final double radiansToDegreesD = 180.0 / Math.PI;
124    /**
125     * Multiply by this to convert from degrees to radians.
126     */
127    public static final double degreesToRadiansD = Math.PI / 180.0;
128
129    /**
130     * Returns the tangent in radians, using a Padé approximant.
131     * Padé approximants tend to be most accurate when they aren't producing results of extreme magnitude; in the tan()
132     * function, those results occur on and near odd multiples of {@code PI/2}, and this method is least accurate when
133     * given inputs near those multiples.
134     * <br> For inputs between -1.57 to 1.57 (just inside half-pi), separated by 0x1p-20f,
135     * absolute error is 0.00890192, relative error is 0.00000090, and the maximum error is 17.98901367 when given
136     * 1.56999838. The maximum error might seem concerning, but it's the difference between the correct 1253.22167969
137     * and the 1235.23266602 this returns, so for many purposes the difference won't be noticeable.
138     * <br> For inputs between -1.55 to 1.55 (getting less close to half-pi), separated by 0x1p-20f, absolute error is
139     * 0.00023368, relative error is -0.00000009, and the maximum error is 0.02355957 when given -1.54996467. The
140     * maximum error is the difference between the correct -47.99691010 and the -47.97335052 this returns.
141     * <br> While you don't have to use a dedicated method for tan(), and you can use {@code sin(x)/cos(x)},
142     * approximating tan() in this way is very susceptible to error building up from any of sin(), cos() or the
143     * division. Where this tan() has a maximum error in the -1.55 to 1.55 range of 0.02355957, the simpler division
144     * technique on the same range has a maximum error of 1.25724030 (about 50 times worse), as well as larger absolute
145     * and relative errors. Casting the double result of {@link Math#tan(double)} to float will get the highest
146     * precision, but can be anywhere from 2.5x to nearly 4x slower than this, depending on JVM.
147     * <br> Based on <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer by Soonts</a>.
148     *
149     * @param radians a float angle in radians, where 0 to {@link #PI2} is one rotation
150     * @return a float approximation of tan()
151     */
152    public static float tan(float radians) {
153        radians *= TrigTools.PI_INVERSE;
154        radians += 0.5f;
155        radians -= Math.floor(radians);
156        radians -= 0.5f;
157        radians *= TrigTools.PI;
158        final float x2 = radians * radians, x4 = x2 * x2;
159        return radians * ((0.0010582010582010583f) * x4 - (0.1111111111111111f) * x2 + 1f)
160                / ((0.015873015873015872f) * x4 - (0.4444444444444444f) * x2 + 1f);
161        // How we calculated those long constants above (from Stack Exchange, by Soonts):
162//        return x * ((1.0/945.0) * x4 - (1.0/9.0) * x2 + 1.0) / ((1.0/63.0) * x4 - (4.0/9.0) * x2 + 1.0);
163        // Normally, it would be best to show the division steps, but if GWT isn't computing mathematical constants at
164        // compile-time, which I don't know if it does, that would make the shown-division way slower by 4 divisions.
165    }
166
167    /**
168     * Returns the tangent in degrees, using a Padé approximant.
169     * Based on <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer</a>.
170     *
171     * @param degrees an angle in degrees, where 0 to 360 is one rotation
172     * @return a float approximation of tan()
173     */
174    public static float tanDeg(float degrees) {
175        degrees *= 1f/180f;
176        degrees += 0.5f;
177        degrees -= Math.floor(degrees);
178        degrees -= 0.5f;
179        degrees *= TrigTools.PI;
180        final float x2 = degrees * degrees, x4 = x2 * x2;
181        return degrees * ((0.0010582010582010583f) * x4 - (0.1111111111111111f) * x2 + 1f)
182                / ((0.015873015873015872f) * x4 - (0.4444444444444444f) * x2 + 1f);
183    }
184
185    /**
186     * Returns the tangent in turns, using a Padé approximant.
187     * Based on <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer</a>.
188     *
189     * @param turns an angle in turns, where 0 to 1 is one rotation
190     * @return a float approximation of tan()
191     */
192    public static float tanTurns(float turns) {
193        turns += turns;
194        turns += 0.5f;
195        turns -= Math.floor(turns);
196        turns -= 0.5f;
197        turns *= TrigTools.PI;
198        final float x2 = turns * turns, x4 = x2 * x2;
199        return turns * ((0.0010582010582010583f) * x4 - (0.1111111111111111f) * x2 + 1f)
200                / ((0.015873015873015872f) * x4 - (0.4444444444444444f) * x2 + 1f);
201    }
202
203    /**
204     * Returns the tangent in radians, using a Padé approximant.
205     * Based on <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer</a>.
206     * @param radians a double angle in radians, where 0 to {@link #PI2} is one rotation
207     * @return a double approximation of tan()
208     */
209    public static double tan(double radians) {
210        radians *= TrigTools.PI_INVERSE_D;
211        radians += 0.5;
212        radians -= Math.floor(radians);
213        radians -= 0.5;
214        radians *= TrigTools.PI_D;
215        final double x2 = radians * radians, x4 = x2 * x2;
216        return radians * ((0.0010582010582010583) * x4 - (0.1111111111111111) * x2 + 1.0)
217                / ((0.015873015873015872) * x4 - (0.4444444444444444) * x2 + 1.0);
218        // how we calculated those large constants above:
219//        return x * ((1.0/945.0) * x4 - (1.0/9.0) * x2 + 1.0) / ((1.0/63.0) * x4 - (4.0/9.0) * x2 + 1.0);
220    }
221
222    /**
223     * Returns the tangent in degrees, using a Padé approximant.
224     * Based on <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer</a>.
225     *
226     * @param degrees an angle in degrees, where 0 to 360 is one rotation
227     * @return a double approximation of tan()
228     */
229    public static double tanDeg(double degrees) {
230        degrees *= 1.0/180.0;
231        degrees += 0.5;
232        degrees -= Math.floor(degrees);
233        degrees -= 0.5;
234        degrees *= TrigTools.PI_D;
235        final double x2 = degrees * degrees, x4 = x2 * x2;
236        return degrees * ((0.0010582010582010583) * x4 - (0.1111111111111111) * x2 + 1.0)
237                / ((0.015873015873015872) * x4 - (0.4444444444444444) * x2 + 1.0);
238    }
239
240    /**
241     * Returns the tangent in turns, using a Padé approximant.
242     * Based on <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/4453027">this Stack Exchange answer</a>.
243     *
244     * @param turns an angle in turns, where 0 to 1 is one rotation
245     * @return a double approximation of tan()
246     */
247    public static double tanTurns(double turns) {
248        turns += turns;
249        turns += 0.5;
250        turns -= Math.floor(turns);
251        turns -= 0.5;
252        turns *= TrigTools.PI_D;
253        final double x2 = turns * turns, x4 = x2 * x2;
254        return turns * ((0.0010582010582010583) * x4 - (0.1111111111111111) * x2 + 1.0)
255                / ((0.015873015873015872) * x4 - (0.4444444444444444) * x2 + 1.0);
256    }
257
258    /**
259     * A smooth sine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th century.
260     * This takes an input in radians, and takes and returns floats.
261     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
262     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of sin(); in particular, only 16384
263     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#sin(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
264     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible sin() returns, you can use this.
265     * <br>
266     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
267     * @param radians an angle in radians; most precise between -PI2 and PI2
268     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
269     */
270    public static float sin(float radians) {
271        //Absolute error:      0.0001498343
272        //Relative error:      0.0000000000
273        //Maximum error:       0.0003550053
274        //Worst input:         -4.2084822655
275        //Worst approx output: 0.8753479123
276        //Correct output:      0.8757029176
277        radians = radians * (TrigTools.PI_INVERSE * 2f);
278        final int ceil = (int) Math.ceil(radians) & -2;
279        radians -= ceil;
280        final float x2 = radians * radians, x3 = radians * x2;
281        return (((11 * radians - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
282    }
283
284    /**
285     * A smooth cosine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th
286     * century. This takes an input in radians, and takes and returns floats.
287     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
288     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of cos(); in particular, only 16384
289     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#cos(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
290     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible cos() returns, you can use this.
291     * <br>
292     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
293     * @param radians an angle in radians; most precise between -PI2 and PI2
294     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
295     */
296    public static float cos(float radians) {
297        //Absolute error:   0.00014983
298        //Relative error:   -0.00000004
299        //Maximum error:    0.00035512
300        //Worst input:      5.77527666
301        //Worst approx output: 0.87340844
302        //Correct output:      0.87376356
303        radians = radians * (TrigTools.PI_INVERSE * 2f) + 1f;
304        final int ceil = (int) Math.ceil(radians) & -2;
305        radians -= ceil;
306        final float x2 = radians * radians, x3 = radians * x2;
307        return (((11 * radians - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
308    }
309
310    /**
311     * A smooth sine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th century.
312     * This takes an input in radians, and takes and returns doubles.
313     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
314     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of sin(); in particular, only 16384
315     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#sin(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
316     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible sin() returns, you can use this.
317     * <br>
318     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
319     * @param radians an angle in radians; most precise between -PI2 and PI2
320     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
321     */
322    public static double sin(double radians) {
323        //Absolute error:   0.00014983
324        //Relative error:   -0.00000000
325        //Maximum error:    0.00035471
326        //Worst input:      -5.21563292
327        //Worst approx output: 0.87566801
328        //Correct output:      0.87602272
329        radians = radians * (TrigTools.PI_INVERSE_D * 2.0);
330        final long ceil = (long) Math.ceil(radians) & -2L;
331        radians -= ceil;
332        final double x2 = radians * radians, x3 = radians * x2;
333        return (((11 * radians - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
334    }
335
336    /**
337     * A smooth cosine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th
338     * century. This takes an input in radians, and takes and returns doubles.
339     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
340     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of cos(); in particular, only 16384
341     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#cos(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
342     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible cos() returns, you can use this.
343     * <br>
344     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
345     * @param radians an angle in radians; most precise between -PI2 and PI2
346     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
347     */
348    public static double cos(double radians) {
349        //
350        radians = radians * (TrigTools.PI_INVERSE_D * 2.0) + 1.0;
351        final long ceil = (long) Math.ceil(radians) & -2L;
352        radians -= ceil;
353        final double x2 = radians * radians, x3 = radians * x2;
354        return (((11 * radians - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
355    }
356
357    /**
358     * A smooth sine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th century.
359     * This takes an input in degrees, and takes and returns floats.
360     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
361     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of sinDeg(); in particular, only 16384
362     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#sinDeg(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
363     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible sinDeg() returns, you can use this.
364     * <br>
365     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
366     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; most precise between -360 and 360
367     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
368     */
369    public static float sinDeg(float degrees) {
370        //Absolute error:   0.00014982
371        //Relative error:   0.00000000
372        //Maximum error:    0.00035495
373        //Worst input:      -299.00579834
374        //Worst approx output: 0.87421572
375        //Correct output:      0.87457067
376        degrees = degrees * (1f / 90f);
377        final int ceil = (int) Math.ceil(degrees) & -2;
378        degrees -= ceil;
379        final float x2 = degrees * degrees, x3 = degrees * x2;
380        return (((11 * degrees - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
381    }
382
383    /**
384     * A smooth cosine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th
385     * century. This takes an input in degrees, and takes and returns floats.
386     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
387     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of cosDeg(); in particular, only 16384
388     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#cosDeg(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
389     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible cosDeg() returns, you can use this.
390     * <br>
391     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
392     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; most precise between -360 and 360
393     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
394     */
395    public static float cosDeg(float degrees) {
396        //
397        degrees = degrees * (1f / 90f) + 1f;
398        final int ceil = (int) Math.ceil(degrees) & -2;
399        degrees -= ceil;
400        final float x2 = degrees * degrees, x3 = degrees * x2;
401        return (((11 * degrees - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
402    }
403
404    /**
405     * A smooth sine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th century.
406     * This takes an input in degrees, and takes and returns doubles.
407     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
408     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of sinDeg(); in particular, only 16384
409     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#sinDeg(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
410     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible sinDeg() returns, you can use this.
411     * <br>
412     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
413     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; most precise between -360 and 360
414     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
415     */
416    public static double sinDeg(double degrees) {
417        //
418        degrees = degrees * (1.0 / 90.0);
419        final long ceil = (long) Math.ceil(degrees) & -2L;
420        degrees -= ceil;
421        final double x2 = degrees * degrees, x3 = degrees * x2;
422        return (((11 * degrees - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
423    }
424
425    /**
426     * A smooth cosine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th
427     * century. This takes an input in degrees, and takes and returns doubles.
428     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
429     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of cosDeg(); in particular, only 16384
430     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#cosDeg(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you need
431     * more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible cosDeg() returns, you can use this.
432     * <br>
433     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
434     * @param degrees an angle in degrees; most precise between -360 and 360
435     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
436     */
437    public static double cosDeg(double degrees) {
438        //
439        degrees = degrees * (1.0 / 90.0) + 1.0;
440        final long ceil = (long) Math.ceil(degrees) & -2L;
441        degrees -= ceil;
442        final double x2 = degrees * degrees, x3 = degrees * x2;
443        return (((11 * degrees - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
444    }
445
446    /**
447     * A smooth sine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th century.
448     * This takes an input in turns, and takes and returns floats.
449     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
450     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of sin(); in particular, only 16384
451     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#sin(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you
452     * need more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible sin() returns, you can use this.
453     * <br>
454     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
455     * @param turns an angle in turns; most precise between -1 and 1
456     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
457     */
458    public static float sinTurns(float turns) {
459        //Absolute error:   0.00014983
460        //Relative error:   0.00000000
461        //Maximum error:    0.00035477
462        //Worst input:      -0.83077192
463        //Worst approx output: 0.87360507
464        //Correct output:      0.87395984
465        turns = turns * 4f;
466        final int ceil = (int) Math.ceil(turns) & -2;
467        turns -= ceil;
468        final float x2 = turns * turns, x3 = turns * x2;
469        return (((11 * turns - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
470    }
471
472    /**
473     * A smooth cosine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th
474     * century. This takes an input in turns, and takes and returns floats.
475     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
476     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of cos(); in particular, only 16384
477     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#cos(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you
478     * need more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible cos() returns, you can use this.
479     * <br>
480     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
481     * @param turns an angle in turns; most precise between -1 and 1
482     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
483     */
484    public static float cosTurns(float turns) {
485        //
486        turns = turns * 4f + 1f;
487        final int ceil = (int) Math.ceil(turns) & -2;
488        turns -= ceil;
489        final float x2 = turns * turns, x3 = turns * x2;
490        return (((11 * turns - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
491    }
492
493    /**
494     * A smooth sine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th century.
495     * This takes an input in turns, and takes and returns doubles.
496     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
497     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of sin(); in particular, only 16384
498     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#sin(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you
499     * need more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible sin() returns, you can use this.
500     * <br>
501     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
502     * @param turns an angle in turns; most precise between -1 and 1
503     * @return the approximate sine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
504     */
505    public static double sinTurns(double turns) {
506        //
507        turns = turns * 4.0;
508        final long ceil = (long) Math.ceil(turns) & -2L;
509        turns -= ceil;
510        final double x2 = turns * turns, x3 = turns * x2;
511        return (((11 * turns - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
512    }
513
514    /**
515     * A smooth cosine approximation (not table-based) built around Bhaskara I's sine approximation from the 7th
516     * century. This takes an input in turns, and takes and returns doubles.
517     * This was updated more recently than the 7th century, and has better precision than the original. You may want to
518     * use this if you notice statistical issues with the tabular approximation of cos(); in particular, only 16384
519     * outputs are possible from {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils#cos(float)}, and about half of those are duplicates, so if you
520     * need more possible results in-between the roughly 8192 possible cos() returns, you can use this.
521     * <br>
522     * Credit to <a href="https://math.stackexchange.com/a/3886664">This Stack Exchange answer by WimC</a>.
523     * @param turns an angle in turns; most precise between -1 and 1
524     * @return the approximate cosine of the given angle, from -1 to 1 inclusive
525     */
526    public static double cosTurns(double turns) {
527        //
528        turns = turns * 4.0 + 1.0;
529        final long ceil = (long) Math.ceil(turns) & -2L;
530        turns -= ceil;
531        final double x2 = turns * turns, x3 = turns * x2;
532        return (((11 * turns - 3 * x3) / (7 + x2)) * (1 - (ceil & 2)));
533    }

535    // ---
536
537    /**
538     * A variant on {@link #atan(float)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs for speed reasons. This can be given a double
539     * parameter, but is otherwise the same as atan(float), and returns a float like that method. It uses the same approximation,
540     * from sheet 11 of "Approximations for Digital Computers." This is mostly meant to be used inside
541     * {@link #atan2(float, float)}, but it may be a tiny bit faster than atan(float) in other code.
542     *
543     * @param i any finite double or float, but more commonly a float
544     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in radians, from {@code -HALF_PI} to {@code HALF_PI} inclusive
545     */
546    public static double atanUnchecked(double i) {
547        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
548        double n = Math.abs(i);
549        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
550        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
551        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
552        double c2 = c * c;
553        double c3 = c * c2;
554        double c5 = c3 * c2;
555        double c7 = c5 * c2;
556        double c9 = c7 * c2;
557        double c11 = c9 * c2;
558        return Math.signum(i) * (QUARTER_PI_D
559                + (0.99997726 * c - 0.33262347 * c3 + 0.19354346 * c5 - 0.11643287 * c7 + 0.05265332 * c9 - 0.0117212 * c11));
560    }
561
562    /**
563     * A variant on {@link #atanTurns(float)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs for speed reasons. This can be given a double
564     * parameter, but is otherwise the same as atanTurns(float), but returns a double in case external code needs higher precision.
565     * It uses the same approximation, from sheet 11 of "Approximations for Digital Computers." This is mostly meant to be used inside
566     * {@link #atan2Turns(float, float)}, but it may be a tiny bit faster than atanTurns(float) in other code.
567     *
568     * @param i any finite double or float, but more commonly a float
569     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in turns, from {@code -0.25} to {@code 0.25} inclusive
570     */
571    public static double atanUncheckedTurns(double i) {
572        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
573        double n = Math.abs(i);
574        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
575        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
576        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
577        double c2 = c * c;
578        double c3 = c * c2;
579        double c5 = c3 * c2;
580        double c7 = c5 * c2;
581        double c9 = c7 * c2;
582        double c11 = c9 * c2;
583        return (Math.signum(i) * (0.125
584                + (0.15915132390848943 * c - 0.052938669438878753 * c3 + 0.030803398362108523 * c5
585                - 0.01853086679887605 * c7 + 0.008380036148199356 * c9 - 0.0018654869189687236 * c11)));
586    }
587
588    /**
589     * A variant on {@link #atanDeg(float)} that does not tolerate infinite inputs for speed reasons. This can be given a double
590     * parameter, but is otherwise the same as atanDeg(float), and returns a float like that method. It uses the same approximation,
591     * from sheet 11 of "Approximations for Digital Computers." This is mostly meant to be used inside
592     * {@link #atan2(float, float)}, but it may be a tiny bit faster than atanDeg(float) in other code.
593     *
594     * @param i any finite double or float, but more commonly a float
595     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from {@code -90} to {@code 90} inclusive
596     */
597    public static double atanUncheckedDeg(double i) {
598        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
599        double n = Math.abs(i);
600        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
601        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
602        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
603        double c2 = c * c;
604        double c3 = c * c2;
605        double c5 = c3 * c2;
606        double c7 = c5 * c2;
607        double c9 = c7 * c2;
608        double c11 = c9 * c2;
609        return (Math.signum(i) * (45.0
610                + (57.2944766070562 * c - 19.05792099799635 * c3 + 11.089223410359068 * c5 - 6.6711120475953765 * c7 + 3.016813013351768 * c9 - 0.6715752908287405 * c11)));
611    }
612
613    /**
614     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, using radians. Average error is
615     * 1.057E-6 radians; maximum error is 1.922E-6. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as
616     * floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians. It is about 4 times faster than
617     * {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 15 ns instead of roughly 60 ns for Math, on Java 8 HotSpot).
618     * <br>
619     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet
620     * 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise. The algorithms on sheets 8-10 are faster, but only by
621     * a very small degree, and are considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)} method, and that cleanly
622     * translates to atan2().
623     *
624     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
625     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
626     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float; ranges from {@code -PI} to {@code PI}
627     */
628    public static float atan2(final float y, float x) {
629        float n = y / x;
630        if (n != n)
631            n = (y == x ? 1f : -1.0f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
632        else if (n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
633        if (x > 0)
634            return (float) atanUnchecked(n);
635        else if (x < 0) {
636            if (y >= 0) return (float) (atanUnchecked(n) + Math.PI);
637            return (float) (atanUnchecked(n) - Math.PI);
638        } else if (y > 0)
639            return x + HALF_PI;
640        else if (y < 0) return x - HALF_PI;
641        return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
642    }
643
644    /**
645     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, using positive or negative degrees.
646     * Average absolute error is 0.00006037 degrees; relative error is 0 degrees, maximum error is 0.00010396 degrees.
647     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
648     * <br>
649     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet
650     * 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise. The algorithms on sheets 8-10 are faster, but only by
651     * a very small degree, and are considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)} method, and that cleanly
652     * translates to atan2Deg().
653     *
654     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
655     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
656     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float; ranges from {@code -180} to {@code 180}
657     */
658    public static float atan2Deg(final float y, float x) {
659        float n = y / x;
660        if (n != n)
661            n = (y == x ? 1f : -1.0f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
662        else if (n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
663        if (x > 0)
664            return (float) atanUncheckedDeg(n);
665        else if (x < 0) {
666            if (y >= 0) return (float) (atanUncheckedDeg(n) + 180.0);
667            return (float) (atanUncheckedDeg(n) - 180.0);
668        } else if (y > 0)
669            return x + 90f;
670        else if (y < 0) return x - 90f;
671        return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
672    }

674    /**
675     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, using non-negative degrees only.
676     * Average absolute error is 0.00006045 degrees; relative error is 0 degrees; maximum error is 0.00011178 degrees.
677     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
678     * <br>
679     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet
680     * 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise. The algorithms on sheets 8-10 are faster, but only by
681     * a very small degree, and are considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)} method, and that cleanly
682     * translates to atan2Deg360().
683     *
684     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
685     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
686     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float; ranges from {@code 0} to {@code 360}
687     */
688    public static float atan2Deg360(final float y, float x) {
689        float n = y / x;
690        if (n != n)
691            n = (y == x ? 1f : -1.0f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
692        else if (n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
693        if (x > 0) {
694            if (y >= 0)
695                return (float) atanUncheckedDeg(n);
696            else
697                return (float) (atanUncheckedDeg(n) + 360.0);
698        } else if (x < 0) {
699            return (float) (atanUncheckedDeg(n) + 180.0);
700        } else if (y > 0) return x + 90f;
701        else if (y < 0) return x + 270f;
702        return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
703    }
704
705    /**
706     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, using non-negative turns only.
707     * Average absolute error is 0.00000030 turns; relative error is 0 turns; maximum error is 0.00000017 turns.
708     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in turns.
709     * Because this always returns a float between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive), it can be useful for various
710     * kinds of calculations that must store angles as a small fraction, such as packing a hue angle into a byte.
711     * <br>
712     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet
713     * 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise. The algorithms on sheets 8-10 are faster, but only by
714     * a very small degree, and are considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(float)} method, and that cleanly
715     * translates to atan2Turns().
716     *
717     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
718     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
719     * @return the angle to the given point, in turns as a float; ranges from {@code 0.0f} to {@code 1.0f}
720     */
721    public static float atan2Turns(final float y, float x) {
722        float n = y / x;
723        if (n != n)
724            n = (y == x ? 1f : -1.0f); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
725        else if (n - n != n - n) x = 0f; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
726        if (x > 0) {
727            if (y >= 0)
728                return (float) atanUncheckedTurns(n);
729            else
730                return (float) (atanUncheckedTurns(n) + 1.0);
731        } else if (x < 0) {
732            return (float) (atanUncheckedTurns(n) + 0.5);
733        } else if (y > 0) return x + 0.25f;
734        else if (y < 0) return x + 0.75f;
735        return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
736    }

738    /**
739     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, using radians. Average error is
740     * 1.057E-6 radians; maximum error is 1.922E-6. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as
741     * doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians. It is about 4 times faster than
742     * {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 15 ns instead of roughly 60 ns for Math, on Java 8 HotSpot).
743     * <br>
744     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet
745     * 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise. The algorithms on sheets 8-10 are faster, but only by
746     * a very small degree, and are considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(double)} method, and that cleanly
747     * translates to atan2().
748     *
749     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
750     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
751     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double; ranges from {@code -PI} to {@code PI}
752     */
753    public static double atan2(final double y, double x) {
754        double n = y / x;
755        if (n != n)
756            n = (y == x ? 1.0 : -1.0); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN
757        else if (n - n != n - n) x = 0.0; // if n is infinite, y is infinitely larger than x.
758        if (x > 0)
759            return atanUnchecked(n);
760        else if (x < 0) {
761            if (y >= 0) return atanUnchecked(n) + Math.PI;
762            return atanUnchecked(n) - Math.PI;
763        } else if (y > 0)
764            return x + HALF_PI_D;
765        else if (y < 0) return x - HALF_PI_D;
766        return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN
767    }

770     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, using positive or negative degrees.
771     * Average absolute error is 0.00006037 degrees; relative error is 0 degrees, maximum error is 0.00010396 degrees.
772     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
773     * <br>
774     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet

833     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in turns.
834     * Because this always returns a double between 0.0 (inclusive) and 1.0 (exclusive), it can be useful for various
835     * kinds of calculations that must store angles as a small fraction, such as packing a hue angle into a byte.
836     * <br>
837     * Credit for this goes to the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation. This is sheet
838     * 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise. The algorithms on sheets 8-10 are faster, but only by
839     * a very small degree, and are considerably less precise. That study provides an {@link #atan(double)} method, and that cleanly
840     * translates to atan2Turns().

844     * @return the angle to the given point, in turns as a double; ranges from {@code 0.0} to {@code 1.0}
845     */
846    public static double atan2Turns(final double y, double x) {

849            n = (y == x ? 1.0 : -1.0); // if both y and x are infinite, n would be NaN

851        if (x > 0) {
852            if (y >= 0)
853                return atanUncheckedTurns(n);
854            else
855                return atanUncheckedTurns(n) + 1.0;
856        } else if (x < 0) {
857            return atanUncheckedTurns(n) + 0.5;
858        } else if (y > 0) return x + 0.25;
859        else if (y < 0) return x + 0.75;
860        return x + y; // returns 0 for 0,0 or NaN if either y or x is NaN

863    /**
864     * Returns arcsine in radians; less accurate than Math.asin but may be faster. Average error of 0.000028447 radians (0.0016298931
865     * degrees), largest error of 0.000067592 radians (0.0038727364 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an
866     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
867     *
868     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
869     * @return between {@code -HALF_PI} and {@code HALF_PI} when a is in the defined range
870     */
871    public static float asin(float a) {
872        float a2 = a * a; // a squared
873        float a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
874        if (a >= 0f) {
875            return HALF_PI
876                    - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - a) * (1.5707288f - 0.2121144f * a + 0.0742610f * a2 - 0.0187293f * a3);
877        }
878        return (float) Math.sqrt(1f + a) * (1.5707288f + 0.2121144f * a + 0.0742610f * a2 + 0.0187293f * a3) - HALF_PI;
879    }
880
881    /**
882     * Returns arcsine in degrees. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
883     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
884     *
885     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
886     * @return between {@code -90} and {@code 90} when a is in the defined range
887     */
888    public static float asinDeg(float a) {
889        float a2 = a * a; // a squared
890        float a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
891        if (a >= 0f) {
892            return 90f
893                    - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - a) * (89.99613099964837f - 12.153259893949748f * a + 4.2548418824210055f * a2 - 1.0731098432343729f * a3);
894        }
895        return (float) Math.sqrt(1f + a) * (89.99613099964837f + 12.153259893949748f * a + 4.2548418824210055f * a2 + 1.0731098432343729f * a3) - 90f;
896    }
897
898    /**
899     * Returns arcsine in turns. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
900     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
901     * Note that unlike {@link #atan2Turns(float, float)}, this can return negative turn values.
902     *
903     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
904     * @return between {@code -0.25} and {@code 0.25} when a is in the defined range
905     */
906    public static float asinTurns(float a) {
907        float a2 = a * a; // a squared
908        float a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
909        if (a >= 0f) {
910            return (float) (0.25 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (0.24998925277680104 - 0.033759055260971525 * a + 0.011819005228947238 * a2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * a3));
911        }
912        return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (0.24998925277680104 + 0.033759055260971525 * a + 0.011819005228947238 * a2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * a3) - 0.25);
913    }
914
915    /**
916     * Returns arccosine in radians; less accurate than Math.acos but may be faster. Average error of 0.00002845 radians (0.0016300649
917     * degrees), largest error of 0.000067548 radians (0.0038702153 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an
918     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
919     *
920     * @param a acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
921     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code PI} when a is in the defined range
922     */
923    public static float acos(float a) {
924        float a2 = a * a; // a squared
925        float a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
926        if (a >= 0f) {
927            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - a) * (1.5707288f - 0.2121144f * a + 0.0742610f * a2 - 0.0187293f * a3);
928        }
929        return PI
930                - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + a) * (1.5707288f + 0.2121144f * a + 0.0742610f * a2 + 0.0187293f * a3);
931    }

933    /**
934     * Returns arccosine in degrees. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
935     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
936     *
937     * @param a acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
938     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code 180} when a is in the defined range
939     */
940    public static float acosDeg(float a) {
941        float a2 = a * a; // a squared
942        float a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
943        if (a >= 0f) {
944            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - a) * (89.99613099964837f - 12.153259533621753f * a + 4.254842010910525f * a2 - 1.0731098035209208f * a3);
945        }
946        return 180f
947                - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + a) * (89.99613099964837f + 12.153259533621753f * a + 4.254842010910525f * a2 + 1.0731098035209208f * a3);
948    }

950    /**
951     * Returns arccosine in turns. This implementation does not return NaN if given an
952     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
953     *
954     * @param a acos is defined only when a is between -1f and 1f, inclusive
955     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code 0.5} when a is in the defined range
956     */
957    public static float acosTurns(float a) {
958        float a2 = a * a; // a squared
959        float a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
960        if (a >= 0f) {
961            return (float) (Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (0.24998925277680104 - 0.033759055260971525 * a + 0.011819005228947238 * a2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * a3));
962        }
963        return (float) (0.5 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (0.24998925277680104 + 0.033759055260971525 * a + 0.011819005228947238 * a2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * a3));
964    }

966    /**
967     * Returns arcsine in radians; less accurate than Math.asin but may be faster. Average error of 0.000028447 radians (0.0016298931
968     * degrees), largest error of 0.000067592 radians (0.0038727364 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an
969     * out-of-range input (Math.asin does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
970     *
971     * @param a asin is defined only when a is between -1.0 and 1.0, inclusive
972     * @return between {@code -HALF_PI} and {@code HALF_PI} when a is in the defined range
973     */
974    public static double asin(double a) {
975        double a2 = a * a; // a squared
976        double a3 = a * a2; // a cubed
977        if (a >= 0.0) {
978            return HALF_PI_D
979                    - Math.sqrt(1.0 - a) * (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * a + 0.0742610 * a2 - 0.0187293 * a3);
980        }
981        return Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * a + 0.0742610 * a2 + 0.0187293 * a3) - HALF_PI_D;
982    }

999    }

1020     * degrees), largest error of 0.000067548 radians (0.0038702153 degrees). This implementation does not return NaN if given an
1021     * out-of-range input (Math.acos does return NaN), unless the input is NaN.
1022     *

1024     * @return between {@code 0} and {@code PI} when a is in the defined range

1033                - Math.sqrt(1.0 + a) * (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * a + 0.0742610 * a2 + 0.0187293 * a3);

1065        }

1069    /**
1070     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital
1071     * Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise). This
1072     * method is usually about 4x faster than {@link Math#atan(double)}, but is somewhat less precise than Math's implementation.
1073     * For finite inputs only, you may get a tiny speedup by using {@link #atanUnchecked(double)}, but this method will be correct
1074     * enough for infinite inputs, and atanUnchecked() will not be.
1075     *
1076     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
1077     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in radians, from {@code -HALF_PI} to {@code HALF_PI} inclusive
1078     * @see #atanUnchecked(double) If you know the input will be finite, you can use atanUnchecked() instead.
1079     */
1080    public static float atan(float i) {
1081        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
1082        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
1083        // again when converted back to float.
1084        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
1085        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
1086        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
1087        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
1088        double c2 = c * c;
1089        double c3 = c * c2;
1090        double c5 = c3 * c2;
1091        double c7 = c5 * c2;
1092        double c9 = c7 * c2;
1093        double c11 = c9 * c2;
1094        return (float) (Math.signum(i) * (QUARTER_PI_D
1095                + (0.99997726 * c - 0.33262347 * c3 + 0.19354346 * c5 - 0.11643287 * c7 + 0.05265332 * c9 - 0.0117212 * c11)));
1096    }
1097
1098    /**
1099     * Arc tangent approximation returning a value measured in positive or negative degrees, using an algorithm from the
1100     * 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm,
1101     * which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
1102     * For finite inputs only, you may get a tiny speedup by using {@link #atanUncheckedDeg(double)}, but this method will be correct
1103     * enough for infinite inputs, and atanUncheckedDeg() will not be.
1104     *
1105     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
1106     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in degrees, from {@code -90} to {@code 90} inclusive
1107     * @see #atanUncheckedDeg(double) If you know the input will be finite, you can use atanUncheckedDeg() instead.
1108     */
1109    public static float atanDeg(float i) {
1110        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
1111        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
1112        // again when converted back to float.
1113        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
1114        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
1115        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
1116        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
1117        double c2 = c * c;
1118        double c3 = c * c2;
1119        double c5 = c3 * c2;
1120        double c7 = c5 * c2;
1121        double c9 = c7 * c2;
1122        double c11 = c9 * c2;
1123        return (float) (Math.signum(i) * (45.0
1124                + (57.2944766070562 * c - 19.05792099799635 * c3 + 11.089223410359068 * c5 - 6.6711120475953765 * c7 + 3.016813013351768 * c9 - 0.6715752908287405 * c11)));
1125    }

1127    /**
1128     * Arc tangent approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study "Approximations for Digital
1129     * Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 11's algorithm, which is the fourth-fastest and fourth-least precise).
1130     * For finite inputs only, you may get a tiny speedup by using {@link #atanUncheckedTurns(double)}, but this method will be correct
1131     * enough for infinite inputs, and atanUncheckedTurns() will not be.
1132     *
1133     * @param i an input to the inverse tangent function; any float is accepted
1134     * @return an output from the inverse tangent function in turns, from {@code -0.25} to {@code 0.25} inclusive
1135     * @see #atanUncheckedTurns(double) If you know the input will be finite, you can use atanUncheckedTurns() instead.
1136     */
1137    public static float atanTurns(float i) {
1138        // We use double precision internally, because some constants need double precision.
1139        // This clips infinite inputs at Double.MAX_VALUE, which still probably becomes infinite
1140        // again when converted back to float.
1141        double n = Math.min(Math.abs(i), Double.MAX_VALUE);
1142        // c uses the "equally-good" formulation that permits n to be from 0 to almost infinity.
1143        double c = (n - 1.0) / (n + 1.0);
1144        // The approximation needs 6 odd powers of c.
1145        double c2 = c * c;
1146        double c3 = c * c2;
1147        double c5 = c3 * c2;
1148        double c7 = c5 * c2;
1149        double c9 = c7 * c2;
1150        double c11 = c9 * c2;
1151        return (float) (Math.signum(i) * (0.125
1152                + (0.15915132390848943 * c - 0.052938669438878753 * c3 + 0.030803398362108523 * c5
1153                - 0.01853086679887605 * c7 + 0.008380036148199356 * c9 - 0.0018654869189687236 * c11)));
1154    }
